title: Question 83

children: A 77-year-old woman is evaluated for fever, chills, and abdominal pain. Six weeks ago, she was hospitalized for gastrointestinal hemorrhage from a bleeding peptic ulcer. She received 2 units of packed red blood cells. She did well until 1 week ago when she noted increasing fatigue, shortness of breath with exertion, and low-grade fevers. She resides in an assisted living facility in Indiana and reports no history of out-of-state travel. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable, and she takes no medications.
On physical examination, temperature is 38.8 °C (101.8 °F); other vital signs are normal. Scleral icterus is noted. The spleen tip is palpable.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Transfusion-transmitted babesiosis should be considered in the differential diagnosis of posttransfusion fever and hemolysis.
This patient with a febrile illness and hemolytic anemia has transfusion-transmitted babesiosis, an erythrocyte infection caused by protozoan parasites in the genus

, the most common cause of babesiosis, is primarily transmitted by the black-legged deer tick, which is endemic in New England, the mid-Atlantic, and the upper Midwest. Transfusion-transmitted disease is less common but likely underrecognized because infected blood products may be shipped to regions where the disease does not normally occur. Furthermore, onset of illness can occur from 1 week to 6 months after transfusion (median onset 37 days), obscuring the link between infection and receipt of blood products.

infection can range from asymptomatic to fulminant and potentially fatal disease, with older adults, immunocompromised patients, and patients with asplenia at highest risk for severe manifestations. Symptoms are often nonspecific, with fever the most common. Physical findings are related to hemolysis and may include splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, and jaundice. Laboratory abnormalities reflect the presence of hemolytic anemia; thrombocytopenia and elevated aminotransferase and alkaline phosphatase levels are also common. Occasionally, the diagnosis is made incidentally in asymptomatic patients when intraerythrocytic rings are seen on a peripheral blood smear.
Cytomegalovirus can be transmitted through transfusion and causes a mononucleosis-like illness with fever, absolute lymphocytosis, and thrombocytopenia but does not commonly cause hemolytic anemia (
Ehrlichiosis is a tick-borne infection that can rarely be transmitted through transfusion (
). Laboratory abnormalities with ehrlichiosis include leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated aminotransferase levels; hemolysis is not seen with this infection.
Leptospirosis can cause fever and cholestasis, but the patient has no compatible history of travel, environmental exposure, or animal exposure to support this diagnosis (
Parvovirus B-19 causes fever and anemia, but the anemia results from red cell aplasia rather than hemolysis (

references: Westblade LF, Simon MS, Mathison BA, et al. Babesia microti: from mice to ticks to an increasing number of highly susceptible humans. J Clin Microbiol. 2017;55:2903-2912.
